Use the file "w support" if you want to try my crude support (which has to be broken away).

A recognizer with detachable legs that can be positioned in the "stomp" position to crush any program trying to get away from the grid...

It's a simple remix of MegaMan's formidable Recognizer. It is a bit higher (lower torso gained connectors), but the proportions are essentially the same, so it should be no trouble to mix in dehart007's dual head face plates.

I mostly worked with Tinkercad, and did a few cuttings with Meshmixer.
(Being new to designing 3D, I struggled for far too long for these simple edits...)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

I'd recommend printing the legs in a way that the "toes" look upward. No supports needed then. Printing them on the side might look nicer, though, but beware warping of the connector.

The torso probably can only be printed on the back, so you might need supports to prevent the holes from caving in.

I printed without supports and had to aggressively prune the connectors to make them work :-/
I might need to rework the connectors, but as I can't trust my printer right now I'm not entirely sure...

This is a quick fit filament oiler for when you are printing PLA on an all metal hotend. It is split for easy fitting with printed hinges and is held together with an elastic band.

Fit some sponge or cloth, add a few drops of cooking oil, close over your filament and secure with an elastic band.

The print in the photo is a bit rough as this printer needs a bit of work.

You can also use this as a filament cleaner/filter if you don't add any oil!

comments.text: Printed this at 30% infill, PLA, and the tabs were so weak they didn't even come off the bed with the holder, they just snapped right away. Maybe you could increase the connectivity between the tabs and the holder pieces?

comments.author: cjalas

comments.text: Nice design, I like that I can add oil or replace the sponge with out removing the filament if needed. Thank you for posting your design.
comments.author: darkrevolution

comments.text: I have never heard of adding oil to PLA for all metal hotends. I've been using an E3D hotend for over 2 years and rarely get jams from PLA.
comments.author: hendo420

comments.text: It may be related to the brand/manufacturer of filament used.
comments.author: hendo420

comments.text: Which version of the E3D hotend are you using? I had a v1 when it was first released and it was metal all the way through. I now have a v6 and it has a ptfe tube that goes well into the heatsink of the hotend. With my v1 I used to get jams. Then I got a bigger spring for my extruder and tweaked the temps alot more and it worked great. The v6 is awesome, unless I screw up the temp really bad it will extrude nearly anything without a  jam. It even works well with TPU which I have heard is a pain in the ass for more people but the E3D v6 prints it very reliably.
comments.author: MarkBenson

comments.text: Chimera - It has a long metal heat-break and the PTFE doesn't go into it.

This endstop switch holder allows adjust its position within 1.5 mm interval approximately with submillimeter accuracy.

Assembling

  1. Put M4 nut into the slider
  2. Connect front and back parts of the moving frame together
  3. Insert the frame with the slider into the clamp (vias for the switch mounting must be on the side of the clamp where is sloped wall)
  4. Insert M4 bolt into the construction and catch the nut inside slider on it (it should looks like on the photo but inside the construction)
  5. Use a couple of another M4 nuts and washer for fixation of the bolt.

title: Upper dishwasher roller hub and clip

description.text: This is the hub for the rollers on the top basket of an LG dishwasher.

Several of these suddenly failed, and I took the opportunity to learn a little openscad.
I printed these in ABS with support.  So far, the ABS has held up just fine in this dishwasher.  The back plate is thicker than the original part because I was having problems with it breaking.
For Version 2 I have lengthened the hub, made the center hole larger, and redesigned the clip.  The idea is to make the clip handle a little more movement so that it stays attached to the basket.

title: Rostock Mini Pro Hot End Mount

description.text:
All the mounts I've seen are for separate hot end and feed tube,or if not, just didn't seem to be quite what I wanted so I made one myself.
The one illustrated is a cheep import the diameter which inserts into the mount is about 16,1 and it fits nice and snugly and the 3 M3 screws with nut inserts lock it in place. I printed in ABS with a 0,35mm nozzle. Hopefully I'll have the Rostock Mini Pro up and running very soon :)

comments.text: Are you using the fans to give better build results with ABS or PLA? Care to share your observations?
comments.author: Hjorvarth

comments.text:
While printing ABS, I use the fans to prevent curling (not to be mistaken for lifting) in small features. I'm seeing, especially in black ABS, it helps keeping the corners flat.
While printing PLA, I use them for the active cooling. Although I have mixed results in printing PLA with the 2x.
comments.author: Hjorvarth

comments.text: I'm currently trying to get ABS to print flat without warping. Is this what you refer to as curling or lifting?  I found a build-plate temperature of 130 C helps a lot, but the absolute best trick I've come across is the ABS / acetone mixture applied to the plate. I've never had an object come loose or warp during a build with a thin layer of ABS applied. On large objects, however, the warping continues even though the first layer remains flat and I get some minor cracking and deformity.  I haven't dabbled with fans yet as I always suspected they would make the warping worse.
comments.author: Flydive

comments.text: Fans won't help against warping, what i called lifting. My solution against warping is hairspray.
comments.author: Hjorvarth

comments.text: If you get the 24V fans from makerbot you can connect them directly to the mightyboard. This means they will turn on automatically after the first couple of layers. Has been working well for me

author: Elija3777

title: Modular Printable Spool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here's a filament spool that can be easily dismantled and assembled in a variety of sizes, without the use of glue or any plastic welding. There are holes provided to secure the assembly with M4 or M3 bolts for the ends, and any small wedge/pin to keep the spars clamped into each end, but you should be able to keep this whole thing together with just a bit of string if you really want. This spool is mainly designed to ride on my Mendel-top spool holder:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8290
However, it should work fine in any other setup with a horizontal axle. You should probably only use it on its side if you have glued/welded the segments together on the bottom.

• Pick a radius for the spool you're making.

    • 120mm should be big enough for reels of plastic up to about 2kg or 4lb, while 150mm should handle heavier reels.

  • Choose a spar for the width of your plastic reel.

    • You can try finding this with a caliper around the sides of the reel or by holding a ruler up to it while holding the filament together. A little compression from the sides can be good to stop the reel getting tangled up.

  • Print and assemble the ends of the spool.

    • Use 608 bearings if you want the spool to have a ridiculously smooth turn, otherwise use a simple bushing.
    • Some light cleaning up of parts might be necessary if you're using 3mm filament like me, though I have done my best to adjust the part tolerances so that it should fit together straight off the printer.

  • Place your reel of filament over one assembled end, and slot the spanning members through holes inside it so that there is light pressure pushing the reel apart.

  • Thread the inside end of the reel through something to secure it, you have all kinds of holes to pick from, so go with a nearby one, or even clamp it to part of the structure with a bulldog clip.

  • Place the other end over the spars and secure the spool from either side with some kind of wedge.
    • A bit of scrap card cut into sharp triangles and slotted through each end hole should do it.

author: vare19

title: S-500 400W Power Supply cover w-switch and AC socket

description.text:
This cover fits the S-500 power supply. This is a 12V, 40A 500W unit.
It has switch and power socket mounting holes. My Power cord is the standard PC PSU power cord. The DC wires are simply brought out thru holes. There is a hole below the socket that I plan on using for a light pipe for the power LED when I find the right one.
There is only a single extra hole needed in the PSU frame on the right side where the lower screw is seen. The left side is held in place by a protrusion that slides in under the PCB and behind the PCB mounting screw so no screws are needed on that side. It is a very solid mount. The edges overlap the frame to make a smooth transition.
The switch hole should be easy to modify for a different snap in switch. The pieces in the center are for bridging support. Cut them out when cleaning it up. The mounting holes for the socket and right side are sized for 3mm plain or thread forming plastic screws (preferred) so nuts are not needed.
12V wires are brought out on the right side via the notch. The left side has a hole for my 12V LED wires. You can remove it if you don't need it.
The rough finish was due to Slic3r. Version 1.2.9 will do a better job, but I updated mine just after the print finished.
I fixed a couple issues on the print and in the file but saw no reason to reprint it. So let me know if you find any more or the fixes I made don't work.

Printed on my newly built CoreXY CBOT using PLA. The bridging on the switch hole may be a little bit of a challenge.
Oh, BTW, you must mount the PSU first as the cover makes the mounting front screws inaccessible.

description.text: This is an attempt at a printable/castable electromagnet. The coil is made from plastic castings and low-melt alloy. There is one base-disk and four coil-disks in the assembly. Each coil-disk has 1.5 turns, so there is a total of 6 turns in the coil. The magnetic core is made from iron powder mixed with epoxy. This electromagnet did not work very well. With a current of tens of amps it can barely move a paperclip. Poor performance is probably mostly due to the low permeability of the magnetic core. It is possible that the same device with a solid iron/steel core would work much better. Maybe you can improve on the design, or at least avoid making the same mistakes that we did. The construction techniques may also be of some interest. We used plastic castings, but the disks can probably be printed or laser-cut. The use of multiple disks avoids the overhang problem common in 3D printers, but it does not capitalize on the printer\'s strengths, such as the ability to print a single part with complex internal geometry. An experimental solid is also uploaded with coils formed from internal cavities. The coil block is about 3cm tall and contains 11.5 turns. The internals were designed to minimize overhangs. I have no idea if this object will print well or not. As a visual aid, an inverse of the coil block is also provided (coilChannel) so you can see what is going on inside the block. If anyone makes a working electromagnet you could put it on this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:329 to make a motor!

Be careful if you actually try to do anything with low-melt alloy.  It is messy, toxic, and hot enough to cause burns.  Use it only if you are experienced working in a lab environment. 
Instructions and more details are in the file Electromagnet.pdf
The AD_PRT files are Alibre Design parametric solid models.  A lightweight version of Alibre is available as freeware.

I hope you post if you improve your experiment.

description.text:
3D printing of optical breadboard and mounts for lasers, lenses, mirrors etc....
I needed something to hold a laser pointer in place so I reckoned I could print something on my trusty Prusa Mendel.

The parts are designed in openSCAD so things are somewhat parametric. They are designed to use the bits of 8 mm smooth rod / threaded bar that are left over from building a RepRap (instead of 1/2" or 12 mm which is common in Physics labs). There are two versions of the optical breadboard. The 'A' one uses quite a lot of material so I designed the 'B' one to use a bit less. Both trap M6 nuts (warm them up and push them into the pla for a tight fit!) and stuff get mounted to the opposite face. The lensholder is setup for 25 mm lens/mirrors and needs 2 M3 nuts and bolts to hold it together. The holderbase is on two parts and the height/length can be varied. The laser holder consists of two rings which contain the laser pointer (using 6 M3 bolts and 6 nuts in traps) and this is coupled to the long section using M3 or M4. The little semi-ring with the hole in it can be used to avoid pushing the pointer button accidently thus saving batteries/eyes.... or hold the button down constantly. Up to date versions of the files can be found here: https://github.com/amk/LaserLab Note: do not stare into laser beam with remaining eye ;-)

comments.text: Very nice optical breadboard set!!

An original twisty puzzle design of mine, based off of a building-block prototype that my friends and I threw together on a rainy day at our middle-school's Rubik's Cube Club. Later, when I saw how even the "non-cubers" at my school enjoyed interacting with and manipulating what we had made, I decided to take it upon myself to build a version that didn't fall apart in their hands, one that was fun and functional. I built prototypes out of wood, clay, legos, and anything else I could find. I tried my hand in resin casting and mold making, all the while attempting to perfect the mechanism. Now here I am, in July, four months later, with what I believe to be the final iteration of the Quasar Puzzle.

I learned a lot about Solidworks while working on this project. In the end, after dozens of different designs that looked better on paper than the real world, I came up with a facepalm-ingly simple design that uses 8x 3/4" 6-32 Machine Screws and 8x 6-32 Hex Nuts to connect 8 identical 3D Printed parts into a simple puzzle. The finished product is wonderful, and I am proud to call this my first original puzzle design.

UPDATE- I will be stickering this in a few weeks.

This project requires...

6-32 1/2" Machine Screws (7x)
6-32 Hex Nut (7x)
QuasarNew.STL (8x)
Glue!

Take two of the 8 identical Quasar Pieces, and screw them together into a 1x1x2, with one oriented so that the open face is on top, and the other so that the open face is on the right. Use the screw and hex nut to connect the two. Repeat with the remaining 6 parts, so that you have 4 identical 1x1x2s. You can glue the nut onto the inner face of each part, while keeping the screw free. This will make it so that the puzzle does not fall apart after a number of turns.

The rest of the assembly can be done intuitively, by looking at the images provided. If you require further help, please ask!

I've been working on this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5264 for a long time and with MBI's recent support of selling the high torque NEMA 17 motors, we can now use some of the heritage designs to create a direct drive, dual stepper extruder. The original design concept comes from the awesome Printruder II, by Zaggo: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1980 With a dual extruder design, it opens up the possibilities of printing in two colors or two different materials, such as ABS for the main structure of the print and PVA for water soluble support material. The offset between nozzles is 35mm.
The BOM to come later in the week, it's got a decent parts list, since you need two of almost everything.

description.text:

author: herbie4206

description.text: Not sure if a 3D printer can handle the top layer or not. May need to print an angled base so this thing can be printed on an angle.

1. Make one 3D hexagon face.
  2. Cut the holes in the face (can cut any shape desired).
  3. Make 11 copies (12 faces total).
  4. Anchor whichever face you want to be the base.
  5. Constrain the edges of the faces together:
    i) Constrain make one edge on the base coincident with one edge on the next face.
    ii) Constrain one edge from the base with one edge on third base and one edge from second face with one edge from third face.
    iii) Each additional face will only require you to constrain it to two edges that are already on the fixed part.
  6. If you have a printer, print this thing! (I don't have one so let me know how it goes)

description.text:
Modernize your next party with these low poly shot glasses! Food safe and easy to print. New design features fewer polygons for a cleaner, sleeker look and an added 0.2oz. from the original 1.5oz.

Printing Tips

  • -You MUST use a 100% infill to ensure food safety and minimize potential holes in the side of the glass
    -Raft and support free printing encouraged
    -Be sure to clean out small threads inside the glass before use

Use Tips

  • -Hand wash only
    -Drink Responsibly

comments.text: Can you size it up?
comments.author: jameskehl

comments.text: it's okay to print that in PLA or i should use specific plastic or stuff because it's porous ?
comments.author: Xylitol

comments.text: You should definitely use PLA to print this. PLA is food safe but only if you print with a 100% infill.
comments.author: Xylitol

comments.text: I printed the original at 20% and it was water tight. I know that there is a reason for you are saying it needs 100% infill, so I have to ask what about it being less than 100% infill makes it less safe?
comments.author: TerryVallery

comments.text: Often the prints will seem water tight, but there may exist very small holes in base of the glass from printing imperfections. This allows small amounts of liquid to become trapped in the infill stucture of the base (the bottom 1/4" of the glass). Once liquid is inside the infill structure, it's impossible to get out. This will encourage bacteria and mildew growth.
comments.author: Froob

comments.text: Instead of using 100% infill you can print it with 2/3 shells, works definitly great on mine ! It might depend of your printer.
comments.author: TerryVallery

The little snap-on connector for the strap on my son's Crocs broke.
5 minutes in openscad, 7 minutes on the T-O-M and it's fixed!
Hopefully it will be durable enough. I resisted the urge to make it snap together, it's designed to be glued.
I also resisted the urge to add some fancy logo to it. Feel free to do so.

Print it.
Clean it up so that they fit together.
I smeared it with a little acetone/ABS slurry in the hope that it would penetrate and make the layers adhere a little better.
Stick the large side in the strap, stick the little side through from inside the shoe and glue them together (I just used the acetone slurry, CA would probably work just as well).

UPDATE, 2/14/2016: This model is now obsolete!
Here's the new one, v3.5 - including a how-to video: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1340624

The latest of my finger prosthetic efforts, now configurable in OpenSCAD format. Choose 1 or 2 segments, and preview changes to all parts in rotated or exploded mode.

See a video in use here: https://youtu.be/lwU__cYSwPI

I'm still working some of the bugs out to ensure that the design is properly parametric. If you find that it is not working well with a certain measurement let me know and I'll take a look.

Update: 11/30/15, I posted a new version 3.2 with many fixes.

Start with preview mode to see changes, and then choose each individual part for printing.

The base, middle section, tip, and linkage I print in PLA. All other parts I do with NinjaFlex. I use 65# braided finishing line, and thin black elastic cord.

I can post more detailed instructions soon if folks would find it helpful.

comments.text: The STLs would just be sized for my fingers, it's really only useful if matched to someone's measurements - which the customizer does for you.  It's NOT possible to scale the STLs to the size needed, because this model requires a high level of accuracy, and stretching the STLs messes with the interface points too much.  That's why I had to take the time to learn OpenSCAD to make a parametric model for the customizer.  Shoot me an email if you keep getting stuck, I can be more responsive there and will try to help!  knick {at} dangercreations {d0t} com

comments.text:
I'm facing problems, because the hinge won't pass through the base...
What parameter is responsible of that?
comments.author: knick

comments.text: If because of width of the middle section not fitting into the base hinge, it would be [hinge_sideclearance].  I like to keep this tight so there's not much wiggle.  This is why I also added the "washers" that are built into the hinge now - as it's much easier to file down the washer slightly to get the right clearance.  These also reduce the friction area for the hinge, making it run smoother.  I also do a little bit of sanding on both sides of the middle section to get it nice and flat/smooth.  [washer_depth_outside] controls how thick these washers are.  Lastly, [hinge_clearance] controls the "vertical clearance" between the curve of the inside part to the curve of the outside part, and that gap is important since the tendons and elastic run through it.  Hope that helps!
comments.author: ItsMeMaker

comments.text:
When I try to use the SCAD file by itself, it tells me there's a parsing error at line 212:
offset = middle_width/2 + hinge_sideclearance2 + hinge_plugclearance2+ hinge_offset+ (explode_distance);
It actually pinpoints the error at the space between "=" and "middle_width/2". How can it be fixed?
comments.author: TimothyChronosParaxade

comments.text: I think I might have figured it out.  I use OpenSCAD on Mac, version 2015.03-1.  In mine it works fine, but I noticed that "offset" was being highlighted in blue, like it was a keyword (such as translate or rotate).  I suspect this behavior might be different across versions and platforms.

title: DEPRECATED - B3 Innovations Pico Extruder fan shrouds customized for Type A Machines 2014 Series 1 (G1)

description.text:
DEPRECATED: I have re-designed these and posted the new and improved "thingy" here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1477168.

For archival purposes: I wanted to improve my prints so I took some elements from a couple other fan shrouds found here on Thingiverse and customized them into fan shrouds that fit the B3 Innovations Pico Extruder as mounted in my Type A Machines 2014 Series 1 (G1). May make some adjustments in the future but these seem to be working for now. Photos are of old flawed design iteration. Printed in ABS to withstand high temperatures. Parts attach with a single screw, and mount directly to Series 1 G1 mount.

So far these shrouds have definitely improved my print quality and success rate (No more jamming!).

Upper_Shroud.stl and Lower_Shroud.stl are the files that should be print ready. Shroud_Assembly.stl is for demonstration purposes only. Mounting holes made for 40mm fans, like the ones that come with and are recommended for Pico extruders.

UPDATE 8-3-15: Added a new "Upper_Shroud_3.5_fixed.stl" which adds space for the flex insert from this post on TAM's forum: http://forum.typeamachines.com/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=620&start=10&hilit=insert

UPDATE 9-16-15: fixed some issues with mounting holes. Still needs some work however.

author: bounty32467

description.text: fragmento de Influencia - Charly Garcia

Mad scientist without a willing assistant? Automate your throw switch.
This is designed to be used with a cheap 9g servo and an arduino, or other microcontroller, to control it.
Control it any way you'd like! You could use bluetooth, IR, voice commands, RFID, motion, temperature, humidity, etc.
This could be a great teaching / learning tool for those getting started with arduino programming.
I do not recommend using this to control a garbage disposal.
https://youtu.be/a7iY0e3OSrc
Can't wait to see how it's used!

1. Print servoThrowSwitch.stl and servoSwitchHandle.stl
    1b. Print "nubbin_alternate" from:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:649284
  2. Attach servo horn to switch handle (I used one of the screws that came with the servo horns)
  3. Insert servo into switch plate (with servo turned fully 'up').
  4. Slide handle into place in 'up' position, and push servo horn onto servo gear.
  5. Program microcontroller. (Happy to help anyone new to this)
  6. Power up & you're all set.

I added the pegs at the bottom to hang an arduino & batteries, but I'll probably update someday with a more elegant solution.

title: Vertical Wind turbine and 3Phase alternator 9 Coils / 12 magnets

description.text:
This is my first alternator design, I'm not an engineer, if you see that something is wrong or have any suggestion or comment will be appreciated.

I've started to think about a 3d printable alternator looking at the Lenz2 Helical Turbine XL, that design is beautiful and effective but is missing of a home makeable generator.
For two weeks I've read all the document I found about generator/alternator/AC and DC current/Rectifier/Charging circuits.
This lead me to my design, a 24 volt 3-phase alternator.
24 volt mean more volt in low speed but a lot in high-speed, almost for sure I'll need to made a MPPT charging circuit.
3-phase seem to be more efficient than a single one but you have to made/buy a 3-phase rectifier that is more expensive.
How many coils and how many windings was the result of a day playing with the Faraday's Law.
Follow the schematics (by Jimmy of Eirbyte) for the star configuration, if you want you can try also a delta configuration, bot will give the same amount of Watts but the star has more Volts and less Ampere and the Delta will have less Volts but more Ampere.
Because I choose to work with MPPT hardware to charge my battery I prefer more Volts.

I'll update this thing constantly during the build process, now we are at revision 0.31

////// NEW DESIGN //////
After a field test on the alternator the result was not satisfying and I choose to redesign the whole stator and rotor to fit bigger coils 5 times more copper than the previous version with smaller wire.
At this point the coils are a bigger then before, for this reason the new design has the coils horizontal.

The new stator design will have 9 coils with 350 turns of 0.6mm wire (old was 50 turns with 1.2mm wire) half of the magnets but twice the size. (40x20x10)

One of the problems of the old design is the difficulty to cast the coils, in the new design the stator arm is also the container for the epoxy resin in this way will be easy to cast the coil when all is working correctly.

After a single coil test seem that the output is around 5V at 2 turns per second, next test will be with the 3 coils connected together.

The next test is 3 coils in series connected with the rectifier and the rectifier is connected to an output capacitor.
Without load the capacitor charge up to around 24,5VDC, with a small load 0.5A the power output is stable at 12VDC

Now is time to cast the coils while printing the blades.
To cast the coil I used a dielectric resin designed for this work, is less expensive then standard epoxy or other type of cast resin.

After casting the first phase, waiting for the wire to be delivered I've started printing the blades, the blade design come from the lenz2 wind turbine, I have remixed some parts to adapt it to my needs.

I suggest using ABS for the parts, PLA melts under direct sunlight in summer (just discovered this today during a field test!) and is more easy to machine if needed.

I've finished to cast all the coils, the generator output around 12V (depend on the load) in a moderate wind dey.
I still waiting for a good windy day to do an appropiate test.

Now I'm printing more blades, the minimum to make the rotor move is around 4/5 layers.
Actually my plan is to test a 6 layers configuration in a moderate wind to see how many Amps I can draw and on this result decide if an additional layer is needed.

Testing with the oscilloscope the curve highlighted that probably my 3'phase rectifier is a bit overrated, the diodes cut to many volts, I want to try some 6A diodes that will cut only 950mv instead of actual diodes that cut around 2v.
I think that in this way I​ will produce less Amps but a more stable rate.

////// OLD DESIGN Pre rev 0.9 //////
The generator is a low rpm designed for a vertical wind turbine.
it may output alternate current (AC) around 24V at 120 RPM.
This current must pass trough a 3 phase rectifier to have a suitable DC current to charge batteries. There two type of rectifiers, half wave and full wave, for efficiency I suggest to buy/build a full wave rectifier.
(in the gallery an image of 3 phase and as they come out from the alternator and the same wave rectified)
(Wave image from Wikimedia by Krishnavedala)
(Rectifier image from Wikimedia by Sonarpulse)

My alternator is made of 18 Coils and 24 Magnets with a Magnets to Coils ratio of 4:1
Inside the gallery there the calculation for coils windings to get 12 or 24 volts.
(I can't be more specific until the first test on the field!)

This design is inspired to the "Lenz2 Helical Turbine XL", I plan to use the wind blades from this design.

The stator is in two pieces, the core and the coils holder.
Print the stator and put your coil in the coil holder, fix it with epoxy and glue the holder to the stator.
The stator will snap in a 90mm tube and will hold a 47mm conic bearing to hold the rotor and the main shaft.
Inside the 90mm tube will be an internal part to hold another 47mm bearing, this two will hold the rotor and the main shaft,

The rotor is in 8 pieces, the main part to print six times and the plates, the part is made to hold 24 40x10x10 N45 magnets.
Handle with care this magnet, they can be dangerous, use eye protection and gloves.

The internal bearing holder is placed inside the 90mm tube and holds the main shaft with a 47mm bearing

To keep the 90mm tube vertical is provided an outer ring to hold 4x20mm tubes at 45deg.

To keep the main shaft in place two rings are provided, one goes on top of the conic bearing inside the stator and one goes at the end of the tube.

I suggest using ABS for the parts, PLA melts under direct sunlight in summer and is more easy to machine if needed.

Rev 0.3 30/6/15 - Modified the inner ring to better fit inside the 90mm tube (that is not really 90mm but a bit smaller)
Rev 0.2 30/6/15 - Modified the coil holders to be adjustable and reduce the gap between coil and magnet
Rev 0.1 30/6/15 - Modified the stator to fit inside my printer.. :) was 2 mm too large.
Rev 0.0 30/6/15 - Design published

Additonal 3d printing and drone racing "stuff" on my youtube channel (iZeeFPV):
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCX7UjdoPqErjrR2nYaxkqCw

Assembly instruction:

Note: if you plan to place the windmill under sunlight use ABS, direct summer sunlight will melt the PLA.

All the part was printed in ABS with 0.3mm layer at a variable speed but around 30-40 mm/s, for all the parts I used a 2 layer raft, 235°C for the nozzle and 95°C for the hotbad, for the big part print it slow.

The build process:

To start print first the legs and the ring designed to hold them.
The legs are 20mm aluminium tube.
Put the 90mm tube inside the ring and snap in the legs, glue the foot at the end of the legs.
Seal all the tube holes with something, I used a liquid foam.

After you have your stable base print the stator and all the 9 coils arm. Each arm stay in place with 2 4mm screw.
The stator will fit nicely the 90mm tube no glue needed but if you prefer you can glue it to the tube.

Now is time to wind the coils with the winder tool, you can use any size of magnet wire you prefer and how many turns but if you exceed the side of the winder tool your coil will not fit inside the arm.
I used 0.7mm wire.
Be sure that all the coil are winded in the same direction!
Cas the coils with a resin you like, but you have to cast it or when they produce power the magnet will lift the coil up and something will broke.
Connect the coil in a delta o star configuration, in my gallery there the schematics for the delta configuration.
Now put the bearing in the stator slot.

Print the bottom bearing holder and the bottom cap
Put the bearing inside the bearing holder and snap it inside the rotor, if needed glue it in place.
Put the cap to seal the 90mm tube.

Print the rotor and 12 rotor arms.
Put the 20mm tube inside the rotor and snap the tube inside the 90mm tube.
The rotor must spin freely.
Now glue the 12 magnet on ....

... To be continued ....

comments.text:
marvelous idea,
How about 3 phase alternator need 6 rectifiers to change to DC.
Look at a car alternator. there are 3 plus and 3 negative rectifiers to make DC current.
Reason not to use car alternator is it could use 40 watts just to magnify coils.
Permanent magnets will need some way to regulate voltage.
I am not telling you how to go forward with this project, but get you to studying how alternators work.
Then there are ready made generator stuff, like starter on Briggs and Straton lawnmower engines cheap. @$100.00 for a good used one.
They have powerful permanet magnets and ready made rotors.
I believe I would consider them, cheap and available. I also think 4 blades that air will go on thru to opposite blade
and use air 2 times. If you lived near S IN,USA, I have some starters I would be glad to donate to practice on. Oh and by the way starters would need extra cooling.
Take care, Live Long and Prosper.

description.text:
Update 04/07 : Just upload an fully monted picture and my work file with all the SolidWorks Files. Hi,
Here is my second version [truly printable] of the 3D printed pinhole box ! On the picture of 3D printed part it's all the test and fail print I do before I have an good one, the final parts are on the front. The pictures are my first test film, taken with this printed box. Sorry for the short description, I haven't time for the moment to write an real instruction notice. Print all the part, bobine two time.
Build your own pinhole or buy one.
I buy mine at stenocamera.fr (use 0.26mm pinhole) but you can easy buid your own, there is a lot of tutorial on the web.
Glue your pinhole on the center of the BotierB part.
Glue some dark fabric on all the part that will be in contact with film, and on the inside of boitierA et boitierB, the top of Bobine et under the Bouchon.
Fix an hexagonal screwdriver head on the bouton part for pull the film.
When it's done you can assemble all piece with ruber band.
(sorry I haven't picture fully assembled, I lend my copy of it for summer before take some...) You can use this pinhole box with both film or photographic paper
For the expose time you can use this little sofware for conversion : http://www.pinhole.cz/en/pinholedesigner/ For the rest your alone, I'll work on a true description with pictures and an real corected english on in september.
I'll upload the design file (SolidWorks) as soon as I can. If you have some questions do not hesitate to ask. For commercial use please ask me before.

remixed_from.title: Azteeg X5 (v1.1 with screw terminals) under-bed mount for Mini Kossel

title: Azteeg X5mini v1.1 mount for Kossel Mini 1515

description.text:
Disclaimer: this mount is a serious pain to wire up. Inserting the stepper and smaller wires through the side holes is quite annoying. I'm going to try to split this into a clamshell and solve a couple of other problems.

I found a few issues in Atomsk's welcome refinement of the original.

I tweaked the scad file to resolve all through holes, fixed a dangling overhang and a few other small tweaks (including the fact that the play button on my boards seems to stick out further than expected), and this is the result.

The scad file requires a recent version of Josef Prusa's functions.scad file to be in the same folder (https://github.com/josefprusa/Prusa3/blob/master/box_frame/inc/functions.scad). Only a beginner to scad here, so go easy on me.

Warning: this is a pain. I recommend holding off until I change this to a clamshell design.

  1. Attach 40x40x10mm fan to end with four M3x12mm screws. I put the screw heads on the inside.

  2. Attach mount to rails with four M3x5mm screws. If you've got them, half-thickness nuts can be tilted into the extrusion while full-thickness nuts will require partial disassembly.

  3. Pass power and heater wires through circular hole, attach to large screw terminals.

  4. Attach board to mount with four M3x5mm screws. I normally chamfer screw holes like this by hand-scraping the top of the screw hole with a 3mm or 1/8" drill.

  5. Strip and tin (if using stranded wire) every stepper wire, thermistor wire, and fan wire.

  6. Insert stripped and tinned wire ends through side holes and tighten screw terminals. For the steppers, I recommend practicing your cussing and having a few original curse words on hand. I decided to curse in Japanese for this exercise, which I found quite satisfying.

comments.author: Heeresflieger1968

description.text:
I had major problems with the print quality when it comes to infills or sharp perimeter turns. The infills were printed bumpy and my nozzle plowed through or rattled over them. Furthermore the second extruder's nozzle bumped also against the print when it crossed the infills.

The guys at Maker's Tool Works said that I have a flowrate issue most likely, i.e. my flowrate is too high. It has surprised me, since I calibrated my extruder as Thomas Sanladerer explains at YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YUPfBJz3I6Y) and got a nearly perfect result.

But after reading the article at http://ohmeye.com/2013/reprap-extrusion-flow-calibration/ I reduce my flowrate from a value of 105 to 98 (about 7%) for my current filament spool. The results are astonishing. No bumps, no crashes, no plowing.

So I build myself these two calibration cubes that helps me to figure out the right flowrate after a filament change. These models don't take long to print but you have enough infill layers to set your flowrate right. Because my printer has a moving bed I made the model longer on the Y axis to see the infill when the bed moves towards me.

First I used the 60mm version (Y axis) but it was a bit to short in my opinion. So I created a 80mm version and provide you both here.

The models where made with Fusion 360 and should be very accurate. So you can also do some more measuring with them.

Since this flowrate calibration cube is designed for a moving bed printer, especially the MendelMax 3, I modeled it with the following settings in mind:

LayerHight: 0.2mm
Nozzle Size: 0.4mm
Max Speed: 60mm/s
Infill density: 100%
Infill pattern: Rectilinear
Top / bottom layers: 1

Set your new flowrate value when the printer is printing the infill pattern parallel to the X axis so you can see the results on the next layer when the pattern gets printed parallel to the longer Y axis. Since some printers have a command buffer, it takes some time for the changes to produce an effect.

So far I used this cube only for PLA filaments at about 210°C with a bed temperature at 60°C

A comfortable guitar winder, optimised for quick printing (35mins for me).

Vitamins:
1x woodscrew;

Min: 3mm threads, 15mm long.

Max: 6mm threads, 28mm long

You can print and then drill it for any screw up to 6mm threads, 28mm long. The plastic surrounding the screw is 10mm dia to allow you to use whatever screw you can find/rob from a door handle.

I tried making them vitamin free but couldn't get anything strong and smooth enough.

Some feedback on the size of the head would be useful as I only have my guitars to measure.

0.3mm layer height, 20% infill.

Whole plate or individual files supplied.

Holes are undersized - ream with drills. This will give you the smooth feeling and good thread engagement.

comments.text: Pretty good model, I had to enlarge the hole where the guitar keys goes with my drill, because the keys are larger on the ESP & LTD guitars. Works great, thank you !

We present an accessory for "Boat" with which we can mount a wireless antenna Ubiquiti NanoStation Loco M2 8dbi, which can reach 5Km away.

Os presentamos un accesorio para "Boat", con el cual podemos montar una antena Wifi Ubiquiti NanoStation Loco M2 de 8dbi, que puede llegar a los 5Km de distancia.

Comunity

Disclaimer

This thing and all other published material cannot be considered as a final product and takes no responsibility of its use.
It must be considered as an experimental and early released product developed by the Innovation and Robotics Department staff with the intention to share it and test it as soon as possible within the community.

Como muestran las imágenes colocar la antena wifi punto 1, en el soporte ref. wifi_support_tube_v1_0 , asegurando con bridas, colocar unas gonas de superglue en la base del tubo y encajar con la pieza ref. wifi_support_ring_v1_0.

Por ultimo colar la pieza wifi_support_ring_v1_0 entre el cuerpo y la cabeza, asegurándolo con tornillos.

Sometimes I run out of USB ports and I need to swap a device from the back of the computer.  I was tired of guessing which black usb cable went to what so I made some cable clips that can be clipped onto the cable.
Sure, you still have to memorize what clip "1" goes to, but at least there is a unique way to identify it now.

I printed it out raftless on the Thing-O-Matic.
There are two files, the one labeled "4 larger clips", has a wider mouth opening and is for fatty USB cables, like the silver shielded ones that come with the TOM.

author: zuari1993

title: Best Clip for Glass Build Platform

description.text:
For 1/4" Glass, on Flashforge Creator

New version of bracket warrants name change from "Better Clip" to "Best Clip", it is now seriously more robust than original version.

Clip features:

  1. 100% printed, No screws, bolts, or nuts
  2. Quick release, for fast glass swaps
  3. Operates as a single clip, no pieces to fumble with
  4. Low profile, good clearance if extruder gets close.

The same assembly fits both the back left corner and the front right corner of glass. Made left and right pivot arms depending on which side of the hole you go in.

Pivot arm designed for easy remixing to cover wider range of thicknesses. If someone wants to remix the pivot arm for a different thicknesses, please link to the bracket here and leave comment with what the remixed pivot arm fits.

If given the mm thickness to add or total clearance needed, I may just do it for you in exchange for a "like". :)

The video is on an old version of the clip, it has been improved since this video.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e3Pgiu3Qea4

UPDATE: 7-1-15 Made V2 of the pivot arms, which stops them from rotating too far from the needed install position. Even easier to use now.

UPDATE 7-4-15: Updated the bracket and added V3 of the kit, for much greater holding pressure on glass. The clip really locks in place now. Deleted old versions, they didn't hold up like I hoped.

UPDATE 8-15-15 After several weeks of usage, the clips got loose, so I added a tighter pivot arm kit that is slightly tighter. Printed using .2 layer height and 3 shells.

UPDATE 12-14-15: Added source files. the FREE Onshape.com site will open .sldprt files, but not the assemblies.

As usual, NO SUPPORTS. I re-printed the brackets with PLA @ 50% to increase durability. If I have any trouble due to heat, I'll simply reprint these clips with ABS @50%.

NOTICE: for best results, when printing two brackets at the same time, position them at a distance far enough from each other to reduce interference from the non-working extruder.

comments.text: I really like the design! I intend to use a more conventional corner bracket for my glass bed, but wanted to thumbs up the effort put in to this, THANKS!
comments.author: InoSiX

comments.text:
Can you make one that will work on the Geeetech I3 Pro X ?
I added glass on it and its great when removing items but tape is not holding the glass in place and I have my glass so its not over the screw .
I do this do to I have to level it some times.
thanks for any help I can get.
comments.author: 3DVRBill

comments.text: Hi, The clips simply hold the glass in place.  Frequent leveling is still required for good prints.  Use only on non-heated bed.
comments.author: 3DVRBill

comments.text: Bad idea, first of all, this is not tight enough to withstand vibration during print, secondly if printed in abs, this will not be strong enough and will bend after 30 minutes printing and the platform will loosen.
comments.author: VladMiami

comments.text: Free free not to use it, but I've been using these clips for months without problems.  Noteworthy is that if I ever print ABS and have to heat the bed, I do go back to the binder clips.

I have printed this design on two printers with abs up to 100% infill. The pivotal arms just snapoff and crack away. They do not have sort of strength. I haven't even tried them on the glass bed yet.... Food for thought I've printed many items, and this portion of the design seems to need some work.
comments.author: krazycanuck2011

comments.text: Krazy,  Thanks for the feedback!  I have been using a couple sets of these clips for a long time now.  I ran the pivot arms through the common mesh tests looking for a problem I might have overlooked.  However the tests did not reveal any obvious problems.  Some slicers make weak joints where multi-bodied parts overlap, which is why I convert my weird shaped parts into a single body.
comments.author: krazycanuck2011

comments.text: UPDATE: My glass is larger than the build platform which is putting outward pressure on the bracket arms.  They are still holding good, but I'm thinking about making a revision where the hole for the pivot arm is centered another few millimeters further under the platform.  This should keep the tension vertical instead of at a slight angle.
comments.author: don3sch

comments.text: Very nice!
comments.author: laird

title: Wave Lamp Base and LED Holder

description.text:
This file is a base for the excellent Wave Lamp part: it fits to the cuved geometry of the base and It has a spiral groove for an LED strip and cabling to be mounted to illuminate the lamp

The wave lamp part can be found here:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:774456

I added a version of the base without the spiral groove for the LED strip. The STL may be invalid with lots of overlapping triangles however it does seem to slice with no problems on GrabCAD Print and Insight
